{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3756390,"name":"","username":"Blazzing_Rose5538","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/6de8d8/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-10-06T16:47:55.961Z","cooked":"

Hi Chief Delphi,

Our team for this upcoming year is switching from tank drive to swerve drive, I wanted to get some others thoughts on a possibly strange control idea that could work. Instead of one joystick controlling the movement and another the orientation, what if you used differential control? Now I understand that you‚Äôd lose the strafe and direct orientation, but what if you used the other directions. If left joystick Y and right Y control forward and back or opposites controlling turn, adding something like left X controls strafe and right X also controls orientation, that allows full range of motion with (what our team is used to) a way to control using tank drive

Build in offseason and adapt. If you use a swerve generator it also eliminates most of the coding and from there it is just tuning. FC swerve is pretty intuitive once you start driving.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-10-06T17:03:37.969Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":203,"readers_count":202,"score":55.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":506911,"topic_slug":"differential-control-scheme-swerve-drive-frc","display_username":"Tim Swartz ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66602,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/differential-control-scheme-swerve-drive-frc/506911/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3756401,"name":"Zac Ogburn","username":"Rowanbladex","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/ce7236/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-10-06T17:04:43.262Z","cooked":"

I can‚Äôt speak on how this would look like on the programming side, but conceptually speaking I‚Äôm skeptical on this being a good idea. to me it sounds like you‚Äôre trying to change the swerve controls to be similar to tank drive, because that is what you‚Äôre used to doing.

Instead, I would push you to try and adopt/implement the existing commonly swerve controls. You might find that newer drivers pick it up easier.

One general piece of advice I give my team commonly is to not stray too far away from what everybody else is doing. If what you are trying to do is vastly different from what everybody else is doing, it‚Äôs less likely that you‚Äôve discovered something super innovative, but instead have missed a key detail for why that thing is so common.

Blazzing_Rose5538:

Now I understand that you‚Äôd lose the strafe and direct orientation

Isn‚Äôt that the point of swerve drive? It sounds like you‚Äôd like to make a tank drive with extra steps.

I‚Äôd ask why you want this. The ‚Äúthis is what we know‚Äù is not a valid reason because you have new freshman and seniors that leave every year. In addition I am 100% sure at least one of your students has picked up a controller and played at least 1 video game during there life in which the controller mappings are similar if not the same. Have your student 5 minutes driving and they will figure out the difference and adapt extremely quickly. There is a reason swerve is overwhelmingly winning in terms of adoption.

I have played around with this concept on kiwi drivetrains, I ended up ditching it, all it does is hinder the strengths of an omnidirectional drive.

However, one thing that may interest you so long as you are committing to having very simple robots or an operator (since this uses more inputs on the driver controller):

  • Left stick for strafe
  • Left and right triggers for rotate
  • Right stick sets the rotation point relative to the robot, so in theory you can orbit a point (such as the reef, or 2017 air ship, or 2008 spider rack) with just the right stick to select a ‚Äúcenter pivot‚Äù and the triggers for speed (orbit rate)
